abstract.t: This specification defines a new HTTP header that can be used by a client to request that certain behaviors be implemented by a server while processing a request.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This specification defines a new HTTP header that can be used by a client to request that certain behaviors be implemented by a server while processing a request.
In this document, the key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: The Prefer Request Header
section.t: The Prefer request-header is used to indicate that particular server behaviors are preferred, but not required, by the client. Prefer is similar in nature to the Expect header defined by with the exception that servers are allowed to ignore a clients stated preferences.

figure.artwork:
Prefer = "Prefer" ":" 1#preference
preference = "return-no-content" | "return-content" | "return-status" | preference-extension preference-extension = token [ "=" ( token | quoted-string ) *prefer-params ] prefer-params = ";" token [ "=" ( token | quoted-string ) ]

section.t: This header is defined with an extensible syntax to allow for future values included in the Registry of Preferences (see ). A server that does not recognize or is unable to comply with particular preference values in the Prefer header of a request MUST ignore those values and MUST NOT stop processing or signal an error.
Comparison of preference values is case-insensitive for unquoted tokens and is case-sensitive for quoted-string preference-extensions.
An HTTP proxy MAY choose to honor a preference even if the origin server does not. The Prefer request-header MUST be forwarded by the proxy if the request is forwarded.

section.title: The Preference-Applied Response Header
section.t: The Preference-Applied response header MAY be included in the response message to indicate which Prefer request header values were honored by the server and applied to the request.

section.title: The "return-no-content" Preference
section.t: The "return-no-content" token indicates that the client prefers that the server not include an entity in the response to a successful request. Typically, such responses would use the 204 No Content status code as defined in Section 10.2.5 of , but other status codes can be used as appropriate.

section.title: The "return-content" Preference
section.t: The "return-content" token indicates that the client prefers that the server include an entity representing the current state of the resource in the response to a successful request.

section.title: The "return-status" Preference
section.t: The "return-status" token indicates that the client prefers that the server include an entity describing the status of the request in the response to a successful request.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The 'Prefer' request header should be added to the permanent registry (see ).

section.title: The Registry of Preferences
section.t: This registry is maintained by IANA and initially contains three values: "return-no-content", "return-content" and "return-status". New assignments are subjects to IESG approval, as outlined in . Requests should be made by email to IANA, which will then forward the request to the IESG, requesting approval. The request should use the following template:

list.t: Preference: (A value for the Prefer request header that conforms to the syntax rule given in )

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Specific preferences requested by a client can introduce security considerations and concerns beyond those discussed in . Implementors must refer to the specifications and descriptions of those preferences to determine the security considerations relevant to each.
